title: Whenever Graves is strong, he immediately becomes overbearing.
body:
Even with the recent mastery changes and lethality nerfs, Graves is just incredibly overbearing to play against.

He:
- Is Tanky
- Is Ranged 
- Is An assassin
- Can deny vision
- Executes you from across the map
- Has some of the best jungle clears in the entire game
- Has an escape or gapcloser

Now, separated, none of these things are necessarily terrible, but put together on one champion, they're just incredibly ridiculous. Due to the nature of Graves' entire kit, whenever he is strong, he becomes immediate pick/ban tier simply because of how _much_ he molds games around him. 

I'm not saying Graves needs another rework, but maybe his identity of being a tanky ranged assassin should be looked at... At least Quinn can be killed without _too_ much hassle. Graves on the other hand? Not so much.

I think that a ranged-DPS jungler doesn't really work as a concept.

Let me explain my thinking:

Almost all junglers are melee.  They have an inherent disadvantage over ranged champions.
Now, of course, the same is true of laners, but the dynamics of a lane are somewhat different.  Melee laners generally don't take (much) damage from the lane itself (e.g. minions), even if they are open to ranged harass and can be zoned by their enemies.
Meanwhile, a jungler is going to be taking damage in their jungle.  Many junglers, especially the weaker ones, will often be at fairly low health levels during their first few clears.

That's why invading the other jungler can work - if you can arrive when they are weakened, or have their abilities on cooldown, you can fight them when you have an advantage.
However, the invaded jungler can still fight back and often win, especially if they saw you coming.

The problem comes in when the invading jungler is ranged.  The melee jungler usually doesn't have the tools to deal with a ranged attacker, especially at early levels, so the ranged jungler can just kite them to death very easily.  Again, lane matchups are slightly different because minion aggro is very important at giving melee laners some indirect protection from harassment, which is lacking in the jungle.

When that ranged champion is also quite good at winning duels even if the melee manages to close the gap, then it starts to become really unfair.  Add in a dash to allow them to escape if the enemy team close in on them, and you end up with a powerful champion who can easily deny the opposing jungler and completely ruin their day, while also scaling to be useful in the late game.

Kindred also had this problem to some extent when they were strong, though in their case it was mostly that their ult made them too hard to kill during invades post-level 6.
